headline: Chicken or Turkey Tetrazzini Deluxe
description: Cooked chicken or turkey breast, pasta, veggies, sherry and broth with creamy and cheesy elements, all baked into a classic. This casserole is a great way to use leftover turkey or chicken. Delicious and freezes well too.
name: Chicken or Turkey Tetrazzini Deluxe
recipeIngredient: 2 (10.75 ounce) cans condensed cream of mushroom soup

recipeInstructions.text: Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add pasta and cook for 8 to 10 minutes or until al dente; drain and set aside.
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).

Meanwhile, melt butter in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add mushrooms, onion and bell pepper and saute until tender. Stir in cream of mushroom soup and chicken broth; cook, stirring, until heated through. Stir in pasta, Cheddar cheese, peas, sherry, Worcestershire sauce, salt, pepper and chicken. Mix well and transfer mixture to a lightly greased 11x14 inch baking dish. Sprinkle with Parmesan cheese and paprika.
Bake in the preheated oven for 25 to 35 minutes, or until heated through.

review.reviewBody: YUMMY! Great way to use turkey leftover from Thanksgiving or Christmas. Used whole wheat spiral noodles instead (healthier!). Substituted 1/2 cup red pepper & 1/2 cup green pepper. Added 1 tbsp minced garlic when cooking down onions & peppers, 1 tsp tumeric, 1 cup sour cream, skipped sherry. Also put drained noodles in lightly greased cake pan then folded mixture (sans cheese) into pan. Then folded cheese in before baking leaving a small layer of cheddar & parmesan cheese atop. Watch closely when it gets to 20 minutes - probably don't need to cook more than 25 or 30 minutes. Pull it out when the edges are looking crispy.
Used fresh Portabella mushrooms and Swapped the Peas for green beans Came out great, Very Tasty

Easy recipe to cut in half, which I did. Made 6 generous servings in a 3 quart casserole. Made it as written except I did add 1.5 teaspoons of chopped garlic, used frozen peas and carrots, and thin spaghetti broken in thirds (makes serving a lot easier). Added some fresh chopped basil and parsley. Used the recommended seasonings, which were right on. Watch the salt. You might not need it because of the sodium content in some of the other ingredients. Can always add the salt after taste testing the sauce. So good! Great meal in a dish. Served with green beans and fresh fruit.
.Used goat cheese instead of cheddar since I was out of it, and topped with parmesan cheese. I also boiled noodles in chicken broth as another viewer suggested. It was delicious!

My family loves this recipe! The only change I make is to substitute 1/4 cup of water plus 1/4 cup apple cider vinegar for the sherry (because we don't drink, it's not something I keep on hand). This works really well! No vinegar taste, and the dish is wonderfully flavorful! -- Note to self: This substitution does not work so well in Ree Drummond's Best Tomato Soup Ever recipe on the food network's website. In combination with everything else in the recipe, the vinegar creates a flavor that seems a bit too acidic.
We love this Recipe so much I have made it twice in two weeks, we eat leftovers for four days. So you could cut it down if you don’t want to eat leftovers for 4 days but we loved it enough to do that
A very good basic start to a one pan dinner. Add a simple salad. Great.

Loved this. Added celery and wilted spinach. Made it in smaller, deeper dish so there was less crusty top and more creamy/saucy chicken an noodles. Makes me want to roast another turkey just to make this Tetrazzini!

This is a very good comfort food casserole. For the meat, one can use chicken, turkey, or even pork, which is what I used. We had some pork loin leftover from Thanksgiving,, 2020 and it was delicious in this casserole. I did not have any frozen peas, so I just left it out and there was plenty of bulk to fill out the mixture. As it was, it nearly overflowed my 9x13 inch baking dish. The grated Parmesan cheese/paprika topping was a great combination of crunch and color. Five stars, for sure.
It was delicious, but a half cup of butter is a lot. Next time i may cut that down to quarter cup and mix the grated parm with panko crumbs to put on top. My husband of course had 2 plates.

I have been making this recipe for years. This is the only Tetrazzini recipe I know. However, I have to leave out the mushrooms and substitute cream of celery soup since my gang won't touch mushrooms. I don't care for them either.
Forgot to mention cooking the pasta in chicken broth for flavor and using leftover chicken which I had baked and seasoned the night before. A great, adaptable recipe!
A little less sherry per my husband

I make a similar tetrazzini with turkey but wanted to change it up a bit. This was very good. I did not use any butter as I minced the onion and added to mixture. I also added petite peas. Omitted the red pepper. Halved the cheddar cheese. Used whole wheat spaghetti. Added thyme and not paprika. Added Greek yogurt. Will make again.
Was very tasty !!
Delicious. Did add 1/2 can of cream of mushroom soup. But overall was really good & very easy to make the recipe your own according to your tastes.

There was no water listed in my recipe. I didnt use peppers. I also used chardonnay instead of cooking sherry and thin spaghetti instead of linguini. I thought the cheddar was an odd choice of cheese; I might try shredded parm next time. Needless to say BF ate two plates. I cooked my chicken in the instant pot, cooled and then added to mixture. I also used baby bella mushrooms. It was very good!
Made exactly. Was so good!
I made it my own a little and loved it! It makes for a large dish, great for sharing.
I add fried onions to the top for a crunch. It’s now on our rotation!

This came out great and was a big hit. Cut recipe in half but used whole, large; green pepper and yellow onion and a little more than half the cheese. Used Monterey Jack cheese and frozen string beans instead of peas because that is what I had on hand. All other quantities were cut in half. This was really very good and an excellent dish to use up left over turkey.

This was delicious! I used shallots instead of onion & sweet red pepper rather than green (was what I had). I also added in a little poultry seasoning and garlic for extra flavour. It was a hit in my home and a great way to use up some of that leftover Christmas turkey! Will definitely make again !!
I loved this. It was very tasty. The only substitution I made was using celery instead of bell pepper.
Great way to utilize leftovers! Very yummy!

Definitely halve the recipe -- even adjusting it to feed 6 was a lot of food! Followed all the directions except swapped white cooking wine for the sherry (pantry issues), and I didn't have a package of frozen peas, so I swapped a package of frozen mixed veggies. Got close to "chicken pot pie" territory with that adjustment, but it was still delish!
I cut the recipe in half and there was still a lot. Tasted good

I added crushed Ritz & White Cheddar Cheez-It crackers with melted butter for a topping. Overall a tasty casserole & a great way to use extra turkey. This makes a lot so be sure you have room in the freezer before you make it to freeze the left overs!
Very tasty and a great way to use a lot of leftover turkey.
I used old fashioned noodles and extra broth and made it more like a soup/stew and it was very good.

This wasn't too bad. I've made enough for myself and had no leftovers. Since I didn't have Worchestershire sauce on hand, I skipped the ingredient. It tasted well without it. I've used cooked chicken breast and would love to try it again with cooked turkey breast someday down the road.
I will make it again. It is a favorite of my husband.

I used brown rice pasta (fettuccini) and Pacific brand organic cream of mushroom soup to make it gluten free. Also substituted chopped celery for the green pepper. I skipped the peas and sherry because I didn't have them. We loved it anyway. I'll try it again WITH peas and sherry.
Very tasty. Simple to make . I reduced the peppers to 1/2 cup and it still turned out well. Will definitely make again.

I've made this twice already (in the past month) because it was so delicious! The second time, since we didn't have cream of mushroom soup, substituted sour cream and fresh mushrooms and it was still delicious. Very rich flavor, a real hit!
Very delicious and easy, will make it again.
My family loved it!
Makes a huge, delicious casserole. Great way to use lots of leftover turkey. However, now I need help eating the casserole!

My fiancee went crazy over this one! I did alter it a bit through the help of other reviews. 1. cut the recipe in half. 2. I omitted the broth (too much liquid). 3. Added 1/2 cup of sour cream, teaspoon of garlic salt, kept the original amount of cheese and covered the dish with more parmesan cheese. I promise I would make this more often!
This is fantastic. I halved the recipe, with no other changes. So so good, thanks!!!
made this as directed, but omitted the sherry, didn't have it in the house. turned out ... spot on!
The flavors were great and it was easy to make. Next time I will reduce the liquid to 1 cup, it was a little runny.
Great recipe!! I wouldn't change a thing. I put mine into two pyrex dishes, since it makes a lot, and froze the second one.
I liked this a lot. It was easy and I used leftover turkey. Will make again with cream of chicken soup to appease my non-mushroom loving son.

This was a very easy recipe to make. I added more chicken broth instead of using sherry. It made one small casserole for tonight's supper and 4 more 2 1/4 lb foil containers for the freezer. Will make again!
It was tasty. I would make it again!
Excellent - but did listen to all the reviews and used much less butter, red pepper, 1 can cream of mushroom and 1 can of cream of celery. Delicious!
Liked it very much but didn't like the parmesan cheese - will use cheddar and bread crumbs melted next time.
I will definitely make it again it was the best pasta I've ever made!my husband isn't impressed but this did it lol.ill always make after Thanksgiving for sure .
I substituted the classic cream of mushroom soup with cream of mushroom soup with garlic. This allows for an extra level of flavor without being overpowering.
Tweaked the recipe to my liking. It was a great recipe to start with.
It was good, however both my husband and myself found it better tasting one to two days later.
My changes included fries onion, garlic, bell pepper and herbs: basil, thyme, oregano. It was wonderful and a great recipe to use this TG leftovers.
I used white wine instead of sherry, and penne instead of spaghetti, and added a bit of dried mustard to the roux It was VERY bland. Needs lots more seasoning.
I halved it for 6 servings. I used angel hair pasta, reduced the sherry to about half than called for, and added about 1/2 cup milk to make it creamier. Delicious and a definite keeper!
It was delicious. Easy to prepare. My family enjoyed it. I will definitely make it again!
Very simple. to make...very good
Would make it again. Changes included (much more-all the left over) turkey and didn't add the alcohol
This recipe is amazing. I totally followed the recipe except left out the peas. Outstanding, very flavorful and easy to whip up with the canned soup.

This meal was great! All plates were cleared which says a lot for the 4 kids under 6 that were at the table. I omitted the bell pepper, used egg noodles in place of the fettuccine and topped with bread crumbs and parmesan cheese. I also halved the recipe and used broth that I made with the leftover turkey carcass per Betty Crocker's directions. This will definitely be put into the dinner rotation.

9/25/16 I've made this many times but forget to review it. I prefer it without the bell peppers. Definitely don't forget the sherry and the peas! 7/30/18 Always a favorite! I use regular sherry, took the advice of another and use celery (not peppers), add tarragon, garlic, homemade mushroom soup (or the like), no added salt. Wonderful...can't get enough of it.
Quick , easy and flavorful! Kids loved it!
Only change I made was red bell pepper instead of green. This is an excellent recipe

This is good, filling, comfort food. Aside from omitting the mushrooms since we don't like them, and cutting the butter from 1/2c. (seriously? 1/2 c. of butter???) to 1 Tbsp. (just enough to saute the peppers and onions), I made this exactly as written. I had to put it into a 13x9 inch dish though, and it filled it completely. My family all enjoyed this, even my picky child ate it.

This is good, filling, comfort food. Aside from omitting the mushrooms since we don't like them, and cutting the butter from 1/2c. (seriously? 1/2 c. of butter???) to 1 Tbsp. (just enough to saute the peppers and onions), I made this exactly as written. I had to put it into a 13x9 inch dish though, and it filled it completely. My family all enjoyed this, even my picky child ate it.

This was a great recipe for leftover Turkey. I did alter the recipe quite a bit but only because i didn't have certain things on hand. I used one cup of white wine and 2 cups of broth. I didn't have any mushrooms so i used veggies on hand. 1/2 cup of frozen corn and 1/2 cup of frozen peas, diced celery and onions. I then thought the dish lacked color so i added some diced green onions and sweet red roasted peppers along with a little parsley. All of this was for color but in the end it really added to the dish. Lastly, i used 2 tsp of worcheschire sauce and added one beaten egg to final mixture to bind dish together. It seemed a bit loose and watery. I topped with parmesean and bread crumbs. I realize i made a lot of changes and perhaps i should post my own recipe but really this recipe was the inspiration and like most cooking we have to improvise or change things to meet our family's taste buds.
I followed the recipe exactly and was disappointed how overwhelming the sherry wine tasted. I recommend using 1/2 of it or less.
I halved the recipe- came out great. Didn't add the sherry as we didn't have any in the house. Still tasted great.

Husband loved it, I did too. I think the recipe would have been great as written, but I did make a few changes. First, I cut the recipe in half. I used dry sherry instead of cooking sherry because it is just plain better and instead of salt, I used Morton's Nature's Seasons Seasoning Blend (a seasoned salt which I think adds great flavor to many dishes instead of just regular salt). Then, only because I didn't have some ingredients called for on hand, I used the following substitutes: spaghetti instead of linguine, canned instead of fresh mushrooms (but I would always use fresh if I had them), red pepper instead of green, and a white cheddar with cranberries. I used slightly more turkey than called for, filling a 2 cup measuring glass to the top, Lastly I didn't measure the Parmesan cheese, but made sure that the top of the casserole was completely covered (so I'm guessing it was slightly more than what half of the recipe would have been since I used the same sized baking dish). I'm adding this one to my favorites! Also, Chardonnay, cheesy baking powder biscuits (or some other great bread), and a small side salad would be good accompaniments for this dish.

I've made this recipe twice now. Once with leftover Thanksgiving turkey and homemade turkey stock, and the second time with leftover chicken and store-bought chicken stock. With the turkey version I followed the recipe except to try bucatini noodles for the first time (which I loved). It turned out delicious, part of which I attribute to the homemade stock, which was very flavorful. The chicken version was also very good and got rave reviews from the family. I used linguine noodles as the recipe called for and made no other changes. I do feel that recipes like this benefit from homemade stock if you can do so ahead of time. All in all, this recipe is definitely a keeper!

As others did, I cut the recipe in half. Here are my changes: used olive oil to sauté the vegetables, left out the bell pepper and peas. With the mushroom soup, used water and bouillon.
My family enjoyed it. Good use for leftover turkey.

This was delicious! What a great way to use the Christmas turkey leftovers! I halved the recipe, my husband and I loved it! As I read in other reviews, I used red pepper instead of green - made the dish more colorful. I also added panko crumbs on the top just before baking. I added hot sauce to the mixture - next time I'm adding more spicing - was good as is, but hubby and I like things a bit more zippy!

Well I thought I had screwed this one up when I discovered that my can of cream of chicken soup was cream of mushroom, but used it anyway and everything was really good. Like others I omitted the bell peppers and followed the rest as posted.
It was very good and I'll make it again....with the correct soup.

Halved the recipe! Made with Turkey, using the left over turkey broth from roasting, and used chopped broccoli instead of peas, also added red, yellow, orange peppers, in addition to the green. Turned out great, family enjoyed!
Added frozen broccolli and Goya seasoning. Used 2 cups cheddar, no parmigiano. Added dry stuffing to bottom of baking dish. Great way to use leftover turkey and stuffing bread.

This was a very tasty recipe that I know I will make many more times. We liked it so much we shared some with our extended families and still had leftovers that we froze for another meal. And that was easy to do since this makes a huge amount, probably enough for 10-12 people! I didn't make any substitutions except for adding a few cloves of garlic and half a red pepper and half a green pepper instead of one while green and it was great! Definitely NOT lo-cal!!! I used Barilla pronto linguini that saved me 2 extra pans-- you gotta try all of their new pronto pastas!!! I also used my stainless steel pan to cook and transfer to the oven instead of transferring to a casserole dish. Thank you for the recipe -- I was so excited how good it tasted and turned out that I forgot to take a picture!! (Next time!)

Made this a second time with our leftover turkey from thanksgiving. This time i didn't add cheddar cheese or chicken broth. We didnt miss the cheddar at all. I only used fresh shaved parm on top. Used wine instead of sherry, added tons of fresh mushrooms and topped with seasoned bread crumbs. . Next time I'll add minced garlic and season the turkey prior to adding it to the veggies and pasta. Ill also used more bread crumbs. Total comfort food.

I made this with leftover turkey from Thanksgiving and it turned out awesome! A couple differences... I used 16oz of rotini noodles instead because I didn't have spaghetti, I only had one can of cream of mushroom soup so I added a little half and half to it, also I had some leftover herbs from Thanksgiving to use up (fresh sage and thyme) so I added those in. I also saw other tetrazzini recipes that called for panko breadcrumbs which sounded good so I sprinkled italian seasoned Panko crumbs on top of the parmesan at the end and dusted the paprika on top (mostly because I forgot to add it earlier). Don't add the extra salt. Parmesan is very salty so that should do the trick. Also, even low sodium cream of mushroom and low sodium broth will add to the saltiness. One watch out if you are using noodles other than spaghetti - it's bulkier and you might need more than one casserole dish to fit it. All in all, this was super flavorful - helped to add a few herbs or italian seasoning to it!

Deleted green pepper, cut mushrooms to 1 cup. Used one cup 1/2 and 1/2 instead of condensed soup and thickened with 1/2 cup flour mixed into melted butter. Used 1 cup fresh, grated Parmesan cheese instead of cheddar. Split into two small casserole dishes and froze one before baking to be served later.
Excellent way to use leftover turkey!

Great recipe! I made it and put most in an 8 x 13" pan. Had enough to put six more servings into another container. Just served the large dish tonight to ten people and had leftovers enough for four more servings. We love turkey and this is a great way to stretch out the leftovers. I used the new "pan size" spaghetti and it was perfect for tetrazzini.

We thought this was good, but not great. All I had on hand were whole wheat linguine noodles, so I know that probably played a role in it. it does make a lot, but we have no problem having leftovers to enjoy for a couple of days.

We enjoyed this dish. It was creamy and not soupy at all. I made it as written. I thought it was a tad salty, my husband liked it that way. I would make it again the next time I have leftover turkey. I don't understand why people give recipes a low rating when they didn't actually make the recipe as written. Stop the insanity! =p Seriously, stop it. You didn't make the recipe. You made your own recipe and screwed it up.

It was delish, followed the recipe.
Perfect for Turkey leftovers.

I made this with one can of cream of mushroom and one can of cream of chicken. I also topped it with a healthy dose of bread crumbs, parmesan cheese and paprika. It is now my go-to recipe for leftover turkey.
This dish is incredibly tasty. The sherry adds a really nice touch, so I add a little more of it and less broth. It tastes just as good after it has been frozen as when freshly made.
Just make sure that you have a huge pan or mix it all in a pot

Kept right with the recipe, except I halved it. You need to take note that the original is for 12 people. I used leftover Rotisserie Chicken for mine and it was great! Luckily the water had already been taken away from the recipe. That's why so many comments talked about it being watery, so no need to cut back on any liquid anymore. I loved the sherry flavor and I'm glad I stuck to the cream of mushroom, they mixed nicely.*****Made it again, but this time with Turkey breast leftovers. Still good!!
REALY GOOD EASY for a group to freeze and have ahead to just heat with salad
The family and company loved it. And we have leftovers. I will make it again.
Recipe is perfect as posted now. I used turkey and chicken drippings for the broth, wheat capellini noodles, mixed veggies, and light butter. Super yummy!!!!
Delicious, though 1 kid wouldn't eat it because of the vegetables. It barely fit in my largest sauce pan so next time I'll add things like peas & sherry before the pasta to make it easier to mix.

Meh. I took the advice of some of the reviewers and used celery instead of bell pepper, and used white wine instead of sherry. I had planned on making my own cream of mushroom soup since once I did it I couldn't in good conscious use the canned stuff again. Well, turns out I didn't have enough mushrooms so ended up using Trader Joe's mushroom soup and I think that ruined it. It just wasn't that interesting. I won't be trying again.

this was awesome.. i used some leftover chopped up chicken breast and cooked it in canola oil, salt and pepper, then threw the veggies in.. halved the broth and cheese and added much more pepper as bf prefers.. i totally forgot the parm and paprika at the end (oops!).. also didn't bother to put this in the oven.. it was good as is.. bf says this is a keeper.. ty so much for the recipe
This is a very good recipe. It makes A LOT so be prepared for leftovers. I used pene pasta and it was good. It barely fit into my largest 9x13 casserole dish. Reheats well.
We enjoyed this very much. I did use Marsala Wine, but I am sure Sherry would have been good also. I also reduced the size to serve 6

Made this last night with leftover turkey. It was wonderful. Although next time I will probably not add the extra salt. It really didn't need it. I also didn't have green pepper, but had yellow. Didn't have sherry and used splash of red wine and red wine vinegar. Not sure how that effected the taste, but end result was great.

I made this today with my leftover turkey from Thanksgiving. I wanted so badly to like it and based on the ingredients we should have loved it. The only thing I omitted was the cooking Sherry. I don't drink and I don't like the taste of wine in my food. So I omitted it. It made up easy but the sauce had an odd taste...I think it was the Worcestershire sauce. I cook with mushroom soup all the time and we love it. But this didn't work for us. My kids didn't like the Parmesan on the top either. I think I would try this again and omit the cheese and the Worcestershire sauce. Also I agree with the other reviews in that this recipe makes A LOT. I would 1/2 the recipe at least until you know you like it.

This dish was excellent. My husband also loved it. The sherry gives it great flavor. The only changes I made were to attempt to make it a bit healthier - only used a quarter of the butter and then some olive oil, and used reduced sodium soup. It does make a large amount, so good for a group, or cut in half.
Loved this recipe. Used leftover smoked turkey from Thanksgiving. Did not add Sherry. Very easy to pull together. Will definitely make again.
